description:
Columbicola columbae is a species of chewing louse that parasitizes domestic pigeons (Columba livia domestica) and other species of pigeons and doves. It is a small, wingless insect that measures approximately 1-2 millimeters in length.

Columbicola columbae belongs to the order Phthiraptera, which includes the suborders Amblycera and Ischnocera. As a chewing louse, it feeds on the feathers, skin, and debris found on the host bird's body. The louse uses its strong mandibles to grasp and chew the feathers and skin of the host.

This species is known to be host-specific, meaning it primarily infests a single host species, in this case, the domestic pigeon. Columbicola columbae can cause irritation, feather damage, and skin lesions in heavily infested birds, which can lead to reduced fitness and potential secondary infections.

The life cycle of Columbicola columbae involves the direct transfer of eggs, known as nits, from the host bird to its offspring during nesting and brooding activities. The nymphs hatch from the eggs and undergo several molts before reaching the adult stage, completing their life cycle on the host bird.

Understanding the biology and ecology of Columbicola columbae is important for managing lice infestations in domestic pigeon populations and maintaining the health and well-being of these birds.
